text: I knew it! I always suspected that half of my remote coworkers were too good to be true.
Only half? Your team must have a high concentration of human talent then.
Or maybe the AI chatbots are just getting better at pretending to be human.
As an AI developer, I find this both fascinating and terrifying. Imagine the job market if this trend continues.
It's a double-edged sword for sure. I wonder if we'll reach a point where companies will have to prove their employees are human.
We'll end up with something like CAPTCHAs for job interviews. "Click all the squares with traffic lights to prove you're human!"
This might explain why the number of remote workers skyrocketed during the pandemic... AI doesn't need to worry about social distancing.
You might be onto something. The pandemic could have been a turning point for the AI chatbot takeover.
Just wait until the AI chatbots figure out how to turn on our webcams during meetings. We'll never be able to tell who's real!
If the study is true, does that mean that 75% of my remote teammates' achievements are actually my AI overlords flexing their capabilities?
That's one way to look at it. I'd rather think of them as your AI "assistants" helping you get more done.
I like the idea of AI teammates, but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't worried about the day they replace me as a project manager.
